results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: What's important to me?
results.creator_credit: Hamish Eden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Hamish Eden is only thirteen, he is uncle to three nephews and a niece. He comes from a large family of twelve but Hamish shares the benefits of having so many brothers and sisters. They have been great role models to Hamish and have taught him many different things, above all the importance of education.

results.title: My family and home town
results.creator_credit: Gerald Phineasa, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Gerald Phineasa loves his family and small community of Bamaga in far North Queensland. His large family have plenty of animals and are starting to race horses and he looks forward to returning from his school break in Brisbane to days of riding and fishing. His town is small but somehow has everything Gerald would want. A loving tribute and a snapshot of a small rural community.

results.title: Both cultures
results.creator_credit: Angel Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Angela Towney’s passion in life is for martial arts, for which she has competed around Australia and, she hopes, internationally. However, she acknowledges and pays homage to the influences that gave her the strength to achieve, her family and community in Wiradjuri country. Despite her father’s earlier troubles, his reform instilled a sense of pride and inner strength which allowed Angel to move beyond the community that she loved to follow her passion. Despite the difficulty of traversing two cultures, the introspection of the East and the Indigenous sense of community, her firey ambition and her innate love of her community and land, Angel recognises that she is enriched and embraced by both.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Angel Towney, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: DST July 09 presents...
results.brief_description: ACMI Digital Storytelling interviews the six participants of the Foundation of Young Australians workshop in July 2009. They are asked questions in regard to the process, what they learned and the experience of telling their stories. This is also intercut with footage from the actual workshop and serves as a behind the scenes documentary to capture the process of Digital Storytelling as well as the impact on the participants.

results.title: Three sisters and three ukuleles
results.creator_credit: T'Kido Titasey, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: T’Kido Titasey dedicates this story to his grandmother. Born a Torres Strait Islander, she never received a formal education but was taught about survival. After World War II, she set up a ukulele band with her two sisters. It became popular and The Mill Sisters travelled around the world and landed a recording deal. Gran’s resourcefulness and eagerness to try new things took her and her sisters on an amazing adventure and has been an immense inspiration to T’Kido.

results.title: What makes me, me
results.creator_credit: Robbie Palm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: One of Robbie Palm’s favourite things is fishing at the creek of his nan’s property. Even though he goes to boarding school in Brisbane, he returns during school holidays to fish. He has been taught by his family the techniques and it is this, and when he plays the Didgeridoo that Robbie feels most connected to his culture. When he plays, he feels proud and watched by his family, both current and past.

results.title: My family
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Dotoi, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: To Malcolm Dotoi, his family includes what he would call his extended family, his cousins and grandfather. They provide support, guidance and inspiration and have helped him to develop into a youth leader. His grandfather, a tribal elder, has taught Malcolm about his connection to the land and to the spiritual world and how all these things have contributed to who Malcolm is today.

results.title: So far, so good
results.creator_credit: Joel Hagan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: A growth spurt sent Joel Hagan into the arena of sports. Finding out he was naturally good at Australian rules, Joel has travelled around Australia, playing football and, later, rugby. Joel’s coaches taught him to be quick off the mark and not to wait for the ball, to go out and get it. These words have inspired Joel, not only in sports but in all aspects of his life and have given him the ambition to pursue a career in journalism in the future.

results.title: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.
results.title_for_label: Spirit, dance and connection = Spirit, dance & connection
results.creator_credit_for_label: Haryne Uta, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Dancing is a way of life, culture and part of our identity. Haryne Uta, a young Torres Strait Islander, started dancing from a very young age. He tells of his journey to not taking it very seriously to realising, under the guidance of his elders, how crucial dancing is to Haryne’s spiritual awakening. The stories of the dance awoke in Haryne a sense of pride and connection to the spiritual world, people and the land.
